properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state on Monday. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of British Columbia. Snow will begin Monday morning and become heavy Monday evening before tapering off Tuesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation of 20 to 30 cm is expected across southeastern BC. For Elk Valley and Kootenay Pass, amounts up to 40 cm are possible. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T14:56:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-20T22:56:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3678227229.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Area: Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state on Monday. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of British Columbia. Snow will begin early Monday morning and intensify during the day across the South Thompson and Shuswap regions. Snowfall amounts will range from 10 to 15 cm before the snow ends Monday night. The Coquihalla Highway will receive 20 cm of snow during the same period. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T21:25:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-21T05:25:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3507579836.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wet snow possible over higher elevations of southern Vancouver Island and the Lower Mainland on Monday. A low pressure system crossing Washington state Monday will bring abundant moisture to southern sections of the south coast. Areas with the heaviest precipitation will see the heavy rain switch over to heavy wet snow above about 150 metres during the day. Precipitation should not be as heavy for northern sections of Vancouver so the snow level will likely be above 200 metres. Snowfall accumulations are uncertain at this time. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T15:29:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-20T23:29:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0400607430.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state on Monday. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of British Columbia. Snow will begin early Monday morning and intensify rapidly. It will taper off late Monday night. Snowfall amounts will range from 25 to 35 cm. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. properties.Summary:

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Torrential rain is expected. Total rainfall: 60 to 100 mm, with locally higher amounts possible, especially over higher elevations just inland from the coast. Locations: southern Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre. Time span: Monday afternoon to Tuesday evening. Remarks: The heavy rain combined with mild temperatures will also cause any existing higher elevation or inland snowpack to melt, adding to the runoff. Additionally, strong southeasterly to southwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h or higher can be expected on Tuesday and wind warnings might be needed for some areas. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-21T18:50:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-21T02:50:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1213642113.2020
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state on Monday. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of British Columbia. Rain over Fraser Canyon - South will switch to heavy wet snow Monday morning and intensify during the day. Within about a 6 hour period snowfall amounts may reach 15 cm or more over higher terrain. The snow will end Monday evening as the low moves to the east. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T20:55:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-21T04:55:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0926589071.2020

Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of British Columbia. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. Total rainfall: possibly reaching 25 mm. Locations: central and northern Nova Scotia. Time span: beginning overnight tonight and continuing into Monday night. Remarks: Rain will begin overnight tonight and persist into Monday night. There is a possibility some counties may reach winter rainfall warning criteria (which is 25 mm in 24 hours). Additionally there is an increasing risk of seeing a period of heavy snow Tuesday over portions of northern Nova Scotia. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T17:49:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-21T01:49:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3742820844.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. Snow, heavy at times is expected to start Monday morning in the Rockies near the British Columbia border and spread eastward to the Saskatchewan border by the evening hours. Total snowfall amounts may reach up to 20 cm in some areas. Snowfall is expected to taper off by late in the day on Tuesday. ### There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm. Locations: eastern mainland of Nova Scotia and Cape Breton. Time span: Monday and Monday night. Remarks: An extended period of rain is forecast, with the heaviest amounts Monday night. Total rainfall amounts could approach 50 mm in some places. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Locations: all of Newfoundland except the south coast from Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre where rainfall warnings have already been issued. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly to southwesterly 80 except locally 110 km/h over exposed areas. The strongest winds are expected on Tuesday. Total rainfall: generally 15 to 30 mm with locally 40 to 60 mm possible over parts of the Burin and southern Avalon peninsulas as well as parts of western Newfoundland. Time span: Monday night through Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A deepening Pacific low will make its way across Washington state on Monday. Abundant moisture associated with the system combined with cold air to the north of its trajectory will produce heavy snowfall across the southern interior of British Columbia. Snow will begin early Monday morning and intensify during the day. It will taper off Monday night. Snowfall amounts will range from 15 to 20 cm for the Nicola and Boundary regions. Snowfall will be more variable in the Okanagan where lower elevations along the lake may receive 10 cm or less; however, there will be 15 cm or more over higher terrain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme windchill values between minus 50 to minus 55 are expected to persist into Monday for Aklavik and Inuvik. For Tuktoyaktuk and Fort Mcpherson regions, the extreme wind chill values are expected to persist until Tuesday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T16:19:13-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Strong northwest winds gusting at times to 70 km/h will produce extreme cold conditions again tonight with windchill values of -55 or lower expected. Windchill values will moderate slightly Monday morning. In addition to the extreme cold, the strong winds will also produce widespread blowing snow with near blizzard conditions. These conditions will persist throughout the night into Monday with gradual improvement expected for Tuesday. This situation may warrant a blizzard warning if visibilities become more restrictive over a longer duration. As a result, the public is advised to listen for possible upgraded warnings. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T16:19:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-21T00:19:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1851410574.2020
Area: Baker Lake

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific low moving eastward just south of Vancouver Island will bring very heavy precipitation to southern Vancouver Island on Monday. Heavy rain will switch over to heavy wet snow in the morning. Within about a 6 hour period snowfall accumulations may exceed 20 cm over higher elevations. The snow will end by late Monday afternoon as the low moves to the east. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm, except 35 cm in the Postville-Makkovik area. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 70 km/h, except 110 along the coast. Locations: central and northern Labrador. Time span: Tuesday into Wednesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin near midday on Tuesday in the Upper Lake Melville area and will spread northward along the coast Tuesday afternoon. Strengthening northerly winds will combine with the snow to cause poor visibilities in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions are possible along the north coast where winds will be strongest. Conditions will improve over the Upper Lake Melville area by early Wednesday morning, but snow and blowing snow may persist until midday Wednesday along parts of the coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-21T18:51:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-21T02:51:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3661954713.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A combination of snow and rain is expected. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm (highest inland). Total rainfall: 15 to 30 mm (highest along southern parts of the coast). Locations: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. Time span: midnight Monday night until overnight Tuesday night. Remarks: Snow will spread over southeastern Labrador around midnight Monday night, and then change to rain over most areas on Tuesday. Significant snowmelt may occur over some locations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values near -55 are anticipated to develop by early monday morning and persist until the late morning hours. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-21T20:04:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-21T04:30:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1834858103.2020
Area: Kugluktuk
